title: 6 Things You Didn't Know About Puerto Rico's Financial Troubles
text:
To say that Puerto Rico is in a lot of financial trouble is like saying that the Titanic just sprung a small leak. As investors, you will want to know how the events in Puerto Rico may affect you and if you have anything to worry about. Here’s what you need to consider.
1. Puerto Rico has the highest debt per capita compared to any state:
If you’re one of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico’s 3.6 million residents, your share of the per capita debt is over $15,000. That’s nearly three times that of Connecticut and more than 15 times the median for all U.S. states.
2. Puerto Rico can’t declare bankruptcy:
Similar to states, Puerto Rico can’t file for bankruptcy. This means that investors can’t rely on the bankruptcy courts, like in the case of Detroit or other municipalities who are allowed to declare bankruptcy, to protect their rights and provide an orderly process to recoup some of their investment. While Puerto Rico’s constitution states that they must pay their debt before any other expenses, it will be a long, complicated and potentially messy process at best.
